answers.title: How to install Kotlin in Eclipse for Android Development?
answers.body:
You can find some information about installing the kotlin-eclipse plugin.

As suggested in this beautiful blog post The Adventurous Developer’s Guide to JVM languages – Kotlin (it's worth reading it) you can always directly ask to kotlin community

answers.title: How to install Kotlin in Eclipse for Android Development?
answers.body:
Install kotlin using the Software Development Kit (SDK) manager And Use Android Studio

Type the following command to install sdk:

$ wget -O sdk.install.sh "https://get.sdkman.io"
$ vi sdk.install.sh
$ bash sdk.install.sh

Type the following commands to install kotlin:

$ source ~/.sdkman/bin/sdkman-init.sh
$ sdk install kotlin

Install JDK

Type the following command :

$ sudo apt-get install openjdk-8-jre-headless

Write your first kotlin program

Create a file called hello.kt:
$ vi hello.kt

Append the following code:

fun main(args: Array<String>) {
    println("Hello, World!")
}

Save and close the file. Compile your app into jar:

$ kotlinc hello.kt -include-runtime -d hello.jar

Run your app:

$ java -jar hello.jar

Enjoy !

title: How to install Kotlin in Eclipse for Android Development?

answers.title: Is there a way to identify a Kotlin data class from a regular Kotlin class?
answers.body:
Since Kotlin 1.1 use isData property on KClass. (docs)

Before Kotlin 1.1 you can try to use some heuristics, like check that it contains next methods:

  • public final copy
  • public final component{N}
  • public static copy$default

Note these implementation details could be changed in the future.

answers.title: Is there a way to identify a Kotlin data class from a regular Kotlin class?
answers.body:
Since 1.1 there is an isData property on the class

MyDataClass::class.isData

title: Is there a way to identify a Kotlin data class from a regular Kotlin class?

comments.body: thanks. is there a way to shorten it to [unused] or something? I tried annotation class unused : suppress("UNUSED_PARAMETER") but it doesn't work due to suppress being final.
You should be able to omit the brackets, that saves two characters :)
Additionally You can extract and share annotation parameter.
My comment applied to the old, now removed annotation syntax and is no longer valid.
I had listenener methods with multiple arguments and only one was used. I was able to set @Suppress("UNUSED_PARAMETER") above the method. So all three unused arguments of four in total are covered :)

answers.title: Mark unused parameters in Kotlin
answers.body:
With the @Suppress annotation You can suppress any diagnostics on any declaration or expression.

Examples: Suppress warning on parameter:

fun foo(a: Int, @Suppress("UNUSED_PARAMETER") b: Int) = a

Suppress all UNUSED_PARAMETER warnings inside declaration

@Suppress("UNUSED_PARAMETER")
fun foo(a: Int,  b: Int) {
  fun bar(c: Int) {}
}

@Suppress("UNUSED_PARAMETER")
class Baz {
    fun foo(a: Int,  b: Int) {
        fun bar(c: Int) {}
    }
}

Additionally IDEA's intentions(Alt+Enter) can help you to suppress any diagnostics:

answers.title: Mark unused parameters in Kotlin
answers.body:
If your parameter is in a lambda, you can use an underscore to omit it. This removes the unused parameter warnings. It will also prevent IllegalArgumentException in the case that the parameter was null and was marked non-null.

See https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/lambdas.html#underscore-for-unused-variables-since-11

comments.body: Why would someone suppress the warning for the entire project?? It is not a good practice.

answers.title: Mark unused parameters in Kotlin
answers.body:
One can disable these warnings by adding a kotlin compile option flag in build.gradle. To configure a single task, use its name. Examples:

compileKotlin {
    kotlinOptions.suppressWarnings = true
}

compileKotlin {
    kotlinOptions {
        suppressWarnings = true
    }
}

It is also possible to configure all Kotlin compilation tasks in the project:

tasks.withType(org.jetbrains.kotlin.gradle.tasks.KotlinCompile).all {
    kotlinOptions {
        // ...
    }
}

If one is using kotlin in Android and want to suppress kotlin compiler warnings, add below in app-module build.gradle file

android{
    ....other configurations
    kotlinOptions {
        suppressWarnings = true
    }
}

Whether you really need to suppress all kotlin warning for your project or not, its up to you.

answers.title: Mark unused parameters in Kotlin
answers.body:
If the functions are part of a class you can declare the containing class open or abstract and the offending methods as open.

open class ClassForCallbacks {
  // no warnings here!
  open fun methodToBeOverriden(a: Int, b: Boolean) {}
}

Or

abstract class ClassForCallbacks {
  // no warnings here!
  open fun methodToBeOverriden(a: Int, b: Boolean) {}
}

title: Mark unused parameters in Kotlin
body:
I am defining some functions to be used as callbacks and not all of them use all their parameters.

How can I mark unused parameters so that the compiler won't give me warnings about them?

comments.body: The multiple-inheritance tag should be removed, this is single inheritance and implementing an interface (Kotlin does not have multiple-inheritance)
If you are not adding the Android tag it is good to create a simplified question example that anyone can work with easily to answer your question. I tried a mocked up version and see no error.
I did that. But still it says expected type is OnClickListener but found SomeActivity. I'm a little confused.
Show us your imports. Are you sure you are implementing the correct OnClickListener?

answers.title: Multiple inheritence in Kotlin
answers.body:
Don't forget to implement onClick(View) function and change onCreate signature. After that code will looks like below:

public class SomeActivity() : Activity(), OnClickListener {

    override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {
        super<Activity>.onCreate(savedInstanceState)

        val someButton = Button(this)

        someButton.setOnClickListener(this)
    }

    override fun onClick(v: View) {
        // TODO implement
    }
}

answers.title: Multiple inheritence in Kotlin
answers.body:
Not wanting to create an Android project, I created a mock up of your classes and there are no errors using the code mentioned in another answer:

// mocked up classes

interface Bundle {}

open class Activity {
    open fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {}
}
interface View {}

interface OnClickListener {
    fun onClick(v: View)
}

open class Button(a: Activity) {
    fun setOnClickListener(o: OnClickListener) {}
}

// the usage, showing no error:

public class SomeActivity() : Activity(), OnClickListener {

    override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {
        super<Activity>.onCreate(savedInstanceState)

        val someButton = Button(this)

        someButton.setOnClickListener(this) // NO ERROR
    }

    override fun onClick(v: View) {
        // TODO implement
    }
}

title: Multiple inheritence in Kotlin
body:
Consider the following example

public class SomeActivity() : Activity(), OnClickListener {

    override fun onCreate(Bundle?: savedInstanceState) {
        super<Activity>.onCreate(savedInstanceState)

        ...

        someButton.setOnClickListener(this) // How do I refer to the `OnClickListener` implementation?
    }
}

How do I refer to the OnClickListener implementation in the above mentioned code snippet?

comments.body: Use AnimationListenerAdapter if you don't need to override all the methods.

answers.title: Accessing properties of enclosing class
answers.body:
A singleton can not be inner, because there is only one instance of it, and instances of inner classes keep references to instances of outer (enclosing) classes. Therefore, singleton objects can not hold references to enclosing classes, and can not access their properties.

As a workaround, use anonymous objects, which are not singletons:

class A(val foo: Int) {

    val listener = object : AnimationListenerAdapter { 
        override fun onAnimationEnd(animation: Animation?) {
            println(foo) // access to outer
        }
    }
}

title: Accessing properties of enclosing class
body:
How do I access the properties of an enclosing class? I am working with singletons in Kotlin.

private object IndeterminateAnimationListener : Animation.AnimationListener {
    override fun onAnimationStart(animation: Animation?) {}

    override fun onAnimationEnd(animation: Animation?) {
        // How do I access the properties of the enclosing
        // from here? 
    }

    override fun onAnimationRepeat(animation: Animation?) {}
}

PS: I can use inner classes, how do I do the same with singletons?

comments.body: Related issue in Kotlin's bugtracker: youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/KT-17989

I'm using classpath "org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-gradle-plugin:$kotlin_version" with ext.kotlin_version = '0.10.770', though the Kotlin Android Studio plugin version I have installed is 0.10.195.25. Thanks for the workaround.

The writer of holdr commented on my question in G+ with: "I have not tried getting it to work with kotlin, but in theory it should. I'm using a method provided by the android plugin "registerJavaGeneratingTask" in order to add the generated sources to the classpath for compilation. It's possible that the kotlin plugin is mucking with things in such a way that the directory is no longer being picked up. It's a bit understandable since this option is hardly documented (The only reference I can find is in the 0.7.0 release notes plus.google.com/+AndroidDevelopers/posts/ersS6fMLxw1)."

Oh, sorry, I actually wanted to ask what Android Gradle plugin do you use. But if the workaround works, maybe there's no problem with that. Anyway, I'll investigate this, it looks like a bug in Kotlin Gradle plugin.
I'm using 'com.android.tools.build:gradle:1.0.1'

Did you find a real fix on this bug? I wrote a plugin to generate code using the registerJavaGeneratingTask method, I can write my Kotlin code, the classes are detected, but on build time, kotlin fails

@badoualy That's the exact problem I'm seeing right now with my Kotlin Android app build scripts. registerJavaGeneratingTask doesn't affect sources for Kotlin classes, and it fails on build time. Did you find any solution for this? Hello from 2019 btw :)

answers.title: Unresolved reference for Holdr in Kotlin
answers.body:
What Kotlin Gradle plugin version do you use?

For now, you could specify the Holdr sources path explicitly as a workaround:

sourceSets {
    ...
    debug.java.srcDirs += 'build/generated/source/holdr/debug'
    release.java.srcDirs += 'build/generated/source/holdr/release'
}

title: Unresolved reference for Holdr in Kotlin
body:
I am trying to use a library called Holdr (https://github.com/evant/holdr) to generate classes based on my layout files to easily reference views in those layouts in my activities.

I can verify that the classes are generated fine at build time 

./gradlew assembleDebug

Class for layout activity_main.xml generates Holdr_ActivityMain.java in 

app/build/generated/source/holdr/

Kotlin gives me two errors during the task 

:app:compileDebugKotlin

Errors

e: (8, 44): Unresolved reference: holdr
e: (12, 24): Unresolved reference: Holdr_ActivityMain

Here is my class

import com.myapp.holdr.Holdr_ActivityMain

public class MainActivity : Activity() {

    private var holdr: Holdr_ActivityMain? = null

    override fun onCreate(savedInstanceState: Bundle?) {
        super.onCreate(savedInstanceState)
        setContentView(R.layout.activity_main)
    }

}

Here is my build.gradle 

apply plugin: 'com.android.application'
apply plugin: 'me.tatarka.holdr'
apply plugin: 'kotlin-android'

android {
    compileSdkVersion 22
    buildToolsVersion "22.0.0"

    defaultConfig {
        applicationId "com.myapp"
        minSdkVersion 22
        targetSdkVersion 22
        versionCode 1
        versionName "1.0"
    }
    buildTypes {
        release {
            minifyEnabled false
            proguardFiles getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android.txt'), 'proguard-rules.pro'
        }
    }
    sourceSets {
        main.java.srcDirs += 'src/main/java'
        main.java.srcDirs += 'src/main/kotlin'
    }
}

dependencies {
    compile fileTree(dir: 'libs', include: ['*.jar'])
    compile "org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-stdlib:$kotlin_version"
}

buildscript {

    ext.kotlin_version = '0.10.770'

    repositories {
        mavenCentral()
    }

    dependencies {
        classpath 'me.tatarka.holdr:gradle-plugin:1.4.1'
        classpath "org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-gradle-plugin:$kotlin_version"
    }
}

repositories {
    mavenCentral()
}

Any help would be appreciated, thank you.
